name: WSJ
text: People tend to favor advisers who are positive, cheerleader-types over tough talkers and voices of experience, recent studies suggest. But such preferences, the researchers also say, often lead to detrimental results. https://t.co/0je4LzazXi

text: About half of the average person’s ability to read facial emotions comes from observing the mouth, nose and chin. Face masks leave the eyes and eyebrows to do all the work. https://t.co/71oZ94s05E https://t.co/eUToDPl2EM

text: "The Woman Who Cracked the Anxiety Code" book review: Claire Weekes flouted the medical establishment of her time, believing that sufferers from anxiety could master themselves and get well https://t.co/FiYUYMfoYC

name: WSJ
text: Doctors Without Borders is ceasing operations at a maternity ward in Kabul that was attacked last month, in a sign of how insecurity continues to plague Afghanistan despite U.S. efforts to reduce violence https://t.co/WOw5TYM2K8

text: Black entertainment professionals say it’s time to go beyond superficial measures; to make real change in Hollywood, they say, more representation in management and creative roles are needed https://t.co/ZcoZB0K7rm

text: Harvard University said it wouldn’t require undergraduate applicants to submit ACT or SAT scores next year, citing “insurmountable challenges in scheduling tests” https://t.co/IWU5rJtLQj

text: Real-estate agents say more home shoppers are looking to buy outside the city, often because they are concerned about a second wave of pandemic-related restrictions https://t.co/p7Du331LQl
